critique: This document is an executive order regarding furloughs for government employees during the fiscal year 1934. It aims to distribute employment during a time when the number of officers and employees exceeded the requirements of the service. It provides regulations for implementing furloughs, distinguishing between those of 90 days or less and those exceeding 90 days. The order also exempts carriers in the Rural Mail Delivery Service from these furlough regulations but authorizes the President to suspend or reduce their allowances for equipment and maintenance. It is difficult to assess a strong ideological tilt. It seems to be a practical measure during a time of economic hardship. There's no direct impact on immigration. The order delegates authority to department heads, but also sets some limits, so it's fairly neutral on executive power. It doesn't strongly favor either federal or state control. It doesn't directly address national security or civil liberties. It involves government intervention in employment, but in a limited way. It doesn't seem to promote or hinder social inclusion. Therefore, most scores are close to neutral.
